message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a neurodegenerative disorder, and the bright red macular spots on fundoscopy are indicative of a lysosomal storage disease. Among the options, only β-hexosaminidase A deficiency (Tay-Sachs disease) is consistent with these findings. Sphingomyelinase deficiency (Niemann-Pick disease type A and B) and ATP-binding cassette transporter mutation (Tangier disease) may also present with neurological symptoms, but do not have the characteristic macular spots. α-galactosidase A deficiency (Fabry disease) may cause renal and cardiac symptoms, but not hypotonia and macular spots.

We refer to information about lysosomal storage disorders for help. The symptoms, hypotonia, developmental delay, and seizures suggest a lysosomal storage disorder. The bright red macular spots and Ashkenazi Jewish descent point to Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in beta-hexosaminidase A enzyme.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease, which involves a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A. The bright red macular spots seen on fundoscopy are characteristic of this disease, and it is also more common among Ashkenazi Jewish individuals. The other options are not associated with the same symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A. The bright red macular spots on fundoscopy are a characteristic finding in Tay-Sachs disease. Sphingomyelinase deficiency causes Niemann-Pick disease, ATP-binding cassette transporter mutation causes adrenoleukodystrophy, and α-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, but these conditions are not associated with the symptoms described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a lipid storage disorder, and among the options, only β-hexosaminidase A deficiency causes the characteristic bright red macular spots and delayed motor development. The patient’s Ashkenazi Jewish descent also increases the likelihood of this diagnosis, as β-hexosaminidase A deficiency is more common in this population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only β-hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with the neurologic symptoms described in the question, such as hypotonia, developmental delays, and seizures. The bright red macular spots seen on fundoscopy are also suggestive of this condition, which is known as Tay Sachs disease. The fact that the patient’s parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent is also relevant, as this population has a higher incidence of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a lysosomal storage disorder. Ashkenazi Jewish descent is also a risk factor for lysosomal storage disorders. Bright red macular spots on fundoscopy are indicative of cherry-red spot, a characteristic feature of Tay-Sachs disease caused by the deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the loss of neck control, inability to roll over, and episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare and eyelid fluttering suggest a neurological disorder. The presence of generalized hypotonia, 3+ deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar reflexes suggest a motor neuron disorder. The bright red macular spots seen on fundoscopy suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A. Sphingomyelinase deficiency is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, ATP-binding cassette transporter mutation causes Tangier disease, and α-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, none of which are consistent with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms and signs of progressive weakness, unresponsiveness with a blank stare, and hypotonia suggest a neurodegenerative disease. The bright red macular spots, known as cherry-red spot, are a diagnostic sign for Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by a deficiency in β-hexosaminidase A. This disease is more common among Ashkenazi Jewish descent.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a neurological disorder, and the bright red macular spots suggest the most likely cause is β-hexosaminidase A deficiency, which is also known as Tay-Sachs disease. The other options are not associated with these symptoms or fundoscopic findings. The patient's Ashkenazi Jewish descent is also a risk factor for Tay-Sachs disease.
